questions.text: A 35 year old woman presented with hairloss as shown in the image. Which of these can be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
In the picture – non scarring alopecia affecting the crown. Also called as fir tree pattern.

Testosterone (androgens) is the cause of androgenic alopecia.

Treatment

questions.text: A 20 year old girl presents with recurrent episodes of swelling on the face associated with abdominal cramps. She has tried multiple over the counter medicines but no relief. Which of these can be used as a treatment?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis here is Hereditary angioneurotic edema (HAE), also called as Quincke disease.

Associated with mutation in SERPING1 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called C1 inhibitor.

Types I and II HAE are inherited as an autosomal dominant trait on chromosome 11q 12.1.

Type III HAE – Gain of function mutations of F12

All types of HAE are aggravated by Oestrogen in contraceptive and hormone replacement therapies

Clinical features

Treatment –

Agents used in the treatment of acute attacks of HAE include the following

C1-INH concentrate:

Kallikrein inhibitor – ecallantide

Selective bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist: Icatibant

Androgen analogues like danazol and tranexamic acid can be used for prophylaxis

questions.text: A 65 year old man presents with a chronic itching at the site of wearing the watch. The doctor notes down the clinical features. All of the following will be written except
questions.solution:
• Lichenification is characterized by thickening of skin with increased skin markings and pigmentation. Dryness of skin/xerosis may also be seen
  • Seen in Chronic dermatitis with long term itching
  • HPE - Acanthosis, increased thickness of stratum spinosum
  • The patient in the question has chronic contact allergic dermatitis to the nickle plating in the watch.

questions.text:
Which of the following are associated with skin disease shown the image

1. Carcinoma stomach
2. Obesity
3. Nicotinic acid
4. Hemochromatosis
questions.solution:
Associations of Acanthosis Nigricans

  • Obesity
  • Insulin resistance, Diabetes mellitus
  • HAIR -AN syndrome, SAPHO syndrome
  • Hyperandrogenism, Cushing syndrome
  • Drugs - Nicotinic acid, Stilbestrol, Corticosteroids, Oral contraceptives
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma

questions.text: This is associated with which syndrome?
questions.solution:
Gardner syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by GI polyps, multiple osteomas, and skin and soft tissue tumors. Cutaneous findings [2] of Gardner syndrome include epidermoid cysts, desmoid tumors, and other benign tumors. Polyps have a 100% risk of undergoing malignant transformation

genetically linked to band 5q21, the adenomatous polyposis coli locus

Cowden syndrome

CS is associated with a predisposition for developing both benign and malignant internal tumours.

autosomal dominant multisystem disease germline mutation in the PTEN tumour suppressor gene in chromosome 10.

Malignancy - breast cancer, Thyroid malignancy, endometrial carcinoma

Cutaneous features in CS include trichilemmomas, acral keratosis, Angiolipomas, Oral mucosal papillomas and fibromas

Muir-Torre syndrome – autosomal dominant genodermatosis germline mutation in the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes

Over 90% of cases are found to have mutations in the MSH2 gene

Diagnostic criteria include the presence of at least one sebaceous neoplasm together with an internal malignancy or the presence of multiple keratoacanthomas and an internal malignancy in a patient with a family history of MTS

MTS has a strong association with colorectal, uterine and ovarian adenocarcinoma; other gastrointestinal malignancies and transitional cancers of the renal tract can also occur.1

Muir-Torre syndrome (MTS) is associated with characteristic cutaneous features, including the development of sebaceous gland neoplasms (Sebaceous adenoma Sebaceous epithelioma Sebaceous carcinoma) and keratoacanthomas

Gorlin Syndrome

  • Synonym: Nevoid Basal Cell Carcinoma
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Underlying cause: Germline mutation of PTCI, a tumor suppressing gene
  • Features: Genodermatoses with Basal cell carcinomas and Multiorgan abnormalities

questions.text: An 8-month old child presented with itchy, exudative lesions on the face, palms and soles. The siblings also have similar complaints. This disease is an example of:
questions.solution:
The patient and siblings are suffering from scabies, caused by the sarcoptes scabiei mite

Public Health Classification of Water Borne Diseases

  • Water borne diseases: Caused by the ingestion of water contaminated by human or animal faeces or urine containing pathogenic bacteria or viruses. Cholera, Typhoid, Amoebic and bacillary dysentery, Viral hepatitis, Leptospirosis, Giardiasis
  • Water washed diseases: Diseases due to lack of water, Poor personal hygiene favours spread. Scabies, Skin sepsis & ulcers, Yaws, Trachoma, Conjunctivitis, Flea/ Lice/ Tick- borne diseases
  • Water based diseases: Caused by parasites found in intermediate organisms living in water, Infecting agents spread by contact or ingestion of water. An essential part of life cycle of agent takes place in aquatic animal Schistosomiasis, Dracunculiasis
  • Water related diseases: Transmitted by insect vectors which breed in water. Yellow fever, Dengue, Encephalitides, Filariasis, Malaria, Onchocerciasis, Trypanosomiasis, Sleeping sickness

questions.text:
A 15 year old girl presents with reddish papules on the face. Which of the following findings may be noted on further examination and investigations

1. Lisch nodule
2. Renal Cortical Cyst
3. Rhabdomyoma of heart and lung
4. Neurofibromas
5. Koenon tumor
questions.solution:
The image depicts - adenoma sebaceoum, also called as facial angiofibroms. These are seen in tuberous sclerosis

Manifestation of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Retinal & optic nerve hamartomas
  • Achromic retinal patches
  • Involvement of skull, spine and pelvis
  • Dental pits
  • Tumors of heart (rhabdomyomas)

Periungual fibroms, also called as koenons tumors

Lisch nodules and neurofibromas are seen in Neurofibromatoses type 1

questions.text: A girl child with verrucous lesions at an age of 2 weeks later on developed linear bands of hyperkeratotic papules and nodules followed by whorled pigmentation. Her mother had history of in-utero child death and hypopigmented atrophic linear lesions. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Incontinentia Pigmenti

Rare X-linked dominant disorder seen only in female

Stages of skin lesion

  • Vesicular: Initial stage, Usually occur in uterus
  • Verrucous papules: Broad linear bands of hyper keratotic papules, seen after healing of the vesicular stage
  • Pigmentation: Typical whorls of brown to slate grey pigmentation Hypopigmentation: Seen sometimes

Associated abnormality:

  • Mental retardation, seizures, microcephaly
  • Skeletal abnormality
  • Delayed and abnormal dentition
  • Ocular defects in 33% of cases.

questions.text: The condition is NOT due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Diagnosis - Phrynoderma

  • Phrynoderma (toad skin) characterized by spiny hyperkeratotic follicular papules
  • Distribution of lesions is bilateral and symmetrical in 70% of patients
  • Disease is localized elbows, knees, extensor extremities, and/ or buttocks
  • Deficiencies of vitamins A and E, B complex vitamins, and essential fatty acids have all been implicated in the etiology of follicular hyperkeratosis
  • Phrynoderma is associated with nutritional deficiencies
  • It is endemic to poor populations but is rare in developed countries
  • In developed countries, phrynoderma most often occurs as a result of malabsorption due to surgical or medical causes, such as small-bowel bypass surgery, colectomy and pancreatic insufficiency.

questions.text: Senear-Usher syndrome is associated with?
questions.solution:
Pemphigus Erythematosus! Senear-Usher Syndrome

May be a combination of localized pemphigus foliaceus and systemic lupus erythematosus, because many of these patients have a positive antinuclear antibody If the eruption becomes more diffuse or generalized, the term pemphigus foliaceus is used

questions.text: Photosensitive rash in common in:
questions.solution:
Erythropoietic proto porphyria

MC childhood porphyria

  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria is rare and presents in early childhood with extreme photosensitivity leading to painful blisters
  • As with other photosensitivity syndromes, the rash can occur rapidly or days after the sun exposure

questions.text: A patient presented with oral ulcers since 3 months and bullae with painful red raw erosions on the skin. A clinical sign was positive. As shown in image. Characteristic microscopic feature of this disease is:
questions.solution:
Clinical Presentation of Pemphigus: Acantholytic Bullae

Pemphigus vulgaris: Supra basal split

  • Nikolsky sign
  • Bulla-spread sign
  • Scalp, face, trunk, mucosal lesions
  • Sepsis and electrolyte imbalance

Pemphigus vegetans: Supra basal split

  • Heaped-up vegetating lesions
  • Groins, axilla, angles of mouth, mucosal

Pemphigus foliaceus: Split in granular layer or just below horny layer

  • Transient superficial bullae rupture to form crusts/ scales

Pemphigus erythematosus: Split in granular layer or just below stratum corneum

  • Less severe form of P. foliaceus
  • Dry, hyperkeratotic lesions on face (malar region)

questions.text: A patient developed bullae without erythema on elbows, knee & sacral area fib crust formation, scarring & milia. He had no photo sensitivity and negative family history for bullous diseases. On DIF IgG deposition at DEJ with no blood vessel involvement is seen probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita (EBA)

  • Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) are a group of inherited blistering diseases that are present from birth BUT EBA is not inherited and usually presents in adult life
  • EBA Me presents as an acquired form of mechan bullous disorder
  • EBA is a rare disease in which tense blisters appear at sites of trauma
  • EBA blisters tend to be localized to areas that are easily injured such as the hands, feet, knees, elbows, and buttocks
  • Sometimes there is mucosal involvement with blisters forming in mouth, nose and eyes
  • EBA may mimic other inflammatory blistering diseases, most often Bullous pemphigoid

questions.text:
A 38 year old man presented with 10 year greyish white plaque with superficial vesicles in the neck and groin. The mother also has similar lesions. Correct regarding this disease is:

1. Steroid no use
2. ATP2Cl impairment
3. Itraconazole can be used
4. Defect in Transglutaminase enzyme
5. Autosomal Recessive inheritance
questions.solution:
Hailey-Hailey Disease

Synonym: Benign familial pemphigus

  • Genetics: Autosomal dominant inheritance, ATP2Cl enzyme haplo-insufficiency

Flexural distribution: Painful erosions, vesico-pustules and scaly erythematous plaques appear at sites of friction such as the sides of the neck, the axillae, the groins and the perineum

Treatment: Not available

questions.text: Lucio's phenomenon is seen in:
questions.solution:
Lucio's Phenomenon

  • An uncommon and unusual reaction that occurs in patients with diffuse Lepromatous leprosy of the 'la bonita' type
  • Characterised by recurrent crops of large, sharply demarcated, ulcerative lesions, affecting mainly the lower extremities, but may generalise and become fatal as a result of secondary bacterial infection and sepsis
  • Patient develops a striking, diffuse skin edema, which tends to efface the age-related wrinkles on the face and gave rise to the historic term, "la belle femme"
  • Hemorrhagic plaques can occur suddenly on the arms, legs, and buttocks, and these eventually lead to widespread severe ulcerations

choices.text: 100 mg Dapsone daily + Rifampicin monthly (600 mg)

questions.text: A patient presented with a single lesion on the right arm. What will be the treatment given?
questions.solution:
• The patient is suffering from single lesion - paucibacillary leprosy

As per latest WHO guidelines, the patient should be given MBMDT for 6 months.

No role of PBMDT now

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant female presented with an indurated painless genital lesion. Inguinal lymph nodes in the groins were enlarged and not tender. The nurse noted erythema at the antibiotic sensitivity test site on the right forearm. What will be the most appropriate next step in management.
questions.solution:
The features described and the image hints towards a diagnosis of syphilis

Demonstration of T. palladium from lesion is the most specific diagnostic test for syphilis

  • Dark ground microscopy is used to demonstrate that T. Pallidum appears as a Corkscrew-shaped organism with characteristic movements (especially angulation)

TOC – inj benzathine penicillin

If pregnant patient allergi c  to penicillin – desensitisation followed by injection BP

If desensitisation fails – oral macrolides (erythromycin/azithromycin)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a NEVUS of melanocyte?
questions.solution:
Nevus of Melanocytes

Acquired nevus: Any melanocytic nevus that is not a congenital nevus or not present at birth or near birth

  • Includes junctional, Compound and Intradermal nevus
  • Junctional nevus: Nevus cells are located along the junction of the epidermis and the underlying dermis. Macule - flat and brown to black.

Compound nevus: A mixture of junctional and intra- dermal proliferation. slightly raised and brown to black

  • Beauty marks are usually compound nevi of either the acquired variety or congenital variety.

Intradermal nevus: Nevus cells are located in the dermis only. raised, most are flesh-colored (not pigmented)

Dysplastic nevus (Nevus of Clark): A compound nevus with cellular and architectural dysplasia. can be flat or raised. markers of risk when they are numerous (Atypical mole syndrome)

Blue nevus: It is blue in color as its melanocytes(spindle shaped nevus cells )

Spitz nevus: A distinct variant of intradermal nevus, usually in a child. Raised and reddish (non-pigmented)

Congenital nevus: Small to large nevus present at or near time of birth

  • Small ones have low potential for forming melanomas, however the risk increases with size, as in the giant pigmented nevus
  • Giant pigmented nevus: Large, pigmented, often hairy congenital nevi , risk of Melanoma

Nevus of Ito and Nevus of Ota: Congenital, flat brownish lesions on the face or shoulder

  • Mongolian spot: Congenital large, deep, bluish discoloration which generally disappears by puberty

questions.text: Which of these can be associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
• Incidences of Squamous cell, carcinoma, Basal cell carcinoma, and Actinic keratosis are markedly increased in patients with Oculocutaneous albinism
  • Interestingly, although rare cases of malignant melanoma are reported in these patients, the incidence does not appear to be markedly elevated

choices.text: Increased reactivity of cutaneous blood vessels to vasodilators
Allergic contact dermatitis due to type 4 hypersesitivity

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 2 year old history of erythematous lesions on the face. The main pathogenesis of this disorder is :
questions.solution:
Diagnostic Features of Rosacea

Middle aged women

  • Comedones absent. Papules, nodules & pustules present
  • Lesions on convexities of face (cheeks, nose & forehead)
  • Spares per orificial area
  • Background erythema and telangiectasia prominent

questions.text: Salt and pepper dyschroma is seen in:
questions.solution:
Skin Manifestations of Scleroderma

  • Raynaud's phenomenon (Most common and earliest symptom)
  • Sclerodactyly and contractures in acral parts
  • Mask-like features
  • Beaking of nose
  • Thinning of lips
  • Radial furrowing around mouth
  • Salt pepper dyschromatopsia
  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Periungual telangiectasia

Intertriginous freckling

Tuberous Sclerosis

  • Classical triad of Tuberous sclerosis:
  • Adenoma sebaceum
  • Epilepsy'
  • Mental retardation

Classical skin lesions of Tuberous sclerosis:

  • Shagreen patch
  • Ash leaf macules
  • Adenoma sebaceum
  • Koenen's tumors (Periungual fibromas)

questions.text: 'Pinch purpura' is diagnostic of:
questions.solution: • Systemic primary systemic (AL) amyloidosis include Waxy papulo nodules and plaques, Ecchymoses, Pinch purpura, and Macroglossia

questions.text: Painful oral ulcer, diagnosis is:
questions.solution: • Aphthous ulcer: Extremely painful ulcer with a necrotic yellow floor surrounded by an erythematous halo

questions.text: This is a disease of?
questions.solution:
Hidradenitis Suppurativa Apocrine Acne

  • Aetiology: Follicular occlusion, a consistent early finding
  • Features: Occlusion of apocrine gland

 

Follicular rupture

  • Perifollicular rupture
  • Perifollicular inflammation
  • Secondary inflammation

questions.text: Only definitive indication of Systemic steroids?
questions.solution:
• Systemic corti co steroids are rarely used in the treatment of Psoriasis
  • Very occasionally its use may be justified in the setting of Generalized psoriasis, Erythrodermic pustular psoriasis or Impetigo herpetiformis (Pustular psoriasis related to pregnancy or the OCP)
  • They are only used for conditions where other treatment is unresponsive or contraindicated or severe enough to require therapeutic trial

Pemphigus neonatorum – staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. Use antibiotics

Von Zumbusch disease – generalised pustular psoriasis, DOC _ acitretin

Lyell’s disease – toxic epidermal necrolysis. Conservative management

questions.text: A known case of diabetes develops skin lesions, which disappear after biopsy. This phenomenon is known as?
questions.solution:
Types of Koebner Phenomena

  • Koebner/Isomorphic phenomena: Skin lesions appearing on lines of trauma; seen in Thermal trauma, Dermatoses

 

Allergic reactions, Therapy

  • True isomorphic phenomena: Lichen planus, Vitiligo, Psoriasis
  • Pseudo-isomorphic phenomena (Infections; due to inoculation of viruses): Warts, Molluscum contagiosum, Behcet's syndrome, Pyoderma gangrenosum Occasional isomorphic phenomena (Localised to trauma-site): Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Lichen sclerosus et atrophicus, Pellagra, Darier's disease, Cancers. Kaposi's sarcoma
  • Reverse Koebner phenomena: Granuloma annulare clears off after biopsy
  • Remote Koebner phenomena: Spontaneous repigmentation of patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites

questions.text: A 8 year old boy presented with patch of partial alopecia with broken hair and easy pluckability of hair. The disease is not caused by:
questions.solution:
• Causative agent of Dermatophytic infections: Keratinophilic fungi
  • Trichophyton
  • Microsporum
  • Epidermophyton
  • Tinea capitis is caused by dermatophytes of Tricho- phyton and Microsporum species only

questions.text: A young girl presented with a lesion over his right ear. The image shows findings on pressing the lesion with a glass slide. The next investigation would be:
questions.solution:
• The subject is having lupus vulgaris because the lesions have central scarring (characteristic of lupus vulgaris)
  • Diascopy - golden yellow nodules (apple jelly nodules) typical of lupus vulgaris
  • Diagnosis of lupus vulgaris is biopsy

questions.text: A 42 yr engineer developed redness of the glans and radial fissuring of the prepuce 2 weeks ago. Which systemic illness should he be screened for?
questions.solution:
This is a case of candidial balanoposthitis

A KOH preparation of scrapings from the glans showed pseudohyphae and buds.

Common in diabetics

Treatment – fluconazole

choices.text: Sturge Weber syndrome is the most likely diagnosis
The photograph reveals Port wine stain
CT Brain will reveal Tram track calcification

questions.text: A neonate presents with persistent seizures and facial nevus as shown in the photograph. The clinician suspects the diagnosis to be a Neurocutaneous syndrome. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

A 50yr old male presented with a single popular fleshcolored lesion on his forehead. On examination it was a dome shaped lesion with central, keratin filled crater. Histopathology of the lesion was performed and the following slide was obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Pembrolizumab is used for which condition?
questions.solution: Pembrolizumab is a new drug for use in treating metastatic melanoma

choices.text: Most common site of involvement is trunk

questions.text: True about Erythema elevatum diutinum:
questions.solution:
Erythema elevatum diutinum:

  1. Rare disease; unknown incidence.
  2. A chronic leukocytoclastic vasculitis typified by a distinctive clinical pattern.
  3. Symmetric, erythematous, violaceous, or yellow-brown papules/nodules/plaques.
  4. Most common sites of involvement are the extensor surfaces of the hands, fingers, elbows, knees, legs, and Achilles tendon. Trunk is usually spared.
  5. Co-occurring diseases include monoclonal paraproteinemias, lymphoproliferative disorders, chronic infection, autoimmune conditions, and connective tissue diseases.
  6. In the early stage of erythema elevatum diutinum (EED), nonspecific leucocytoclastic vasculitis is observed. In later stages, granulation tissue and fibrosis form with a diffuse mixed-cell infiltrate showing a predominance of neutrophils. The capillaries may still show deposits of fibrinoid material or merely fibrous thickening.
  7. Dapsone- and sulfone-based therapies are considered first-line treatment choices for EED

choices.text: A squamous cell carcinoma is likely to develop
You should stop taking all medications
These lesions will probably resolve over time

questions.text: A dentist notices that his 39-yr lady patient has some lesions on the buccal mucosa. She says that these lesions have been present for a year. She also has some pruritic, purple papules on forearms. A biopsy of a skin lesion shows a band like infiltrate of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction along with degeneration of basal keratinocytes. What would you advise the patient?
questions.solution: This patient has the classic 'pruritic, purple, polygonal papules' of lichen planus, with the distinctive band like infiltrate of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction. The lesions of lichen planus are typically self limited, although the course can run several years. Oral lesions may persist longer. There is no risk for malignancy. Although a lymphocytic infiltrate is present, an infectious or autoimmune cause is not implicated. A drug' eruption should not last this long. Lesions of erythema multiforme are more likely to follow infection drugs, autoimmune diseases, and malignancies

questions.text: The following Image shows:
Identify the device:

choices.text: Anterior aspects of legs and forearms

questions.text: Idiopathic guttate hypomelanosis usually occurs over the-
A patient presented with multiple red, purple, flesh-colored, or colorless papules on the right arm. He is known to be HIV positive. These lesions are caused by:
questions.solution: Bacillary angiomatosis, a treatable opportunistic infection, was initially reported as atypical subcutaneous infection in patients with advanced HIV disease and as epithelioid angiomatosis. The agents causing this infection, initially designated as Rochalimaea, have been reclassified as Bartonella. The term bacillary angiomatosis is being replaced by Bartonella infection because the infectious agents causing this condition have been identified as two species of Bartonella - B. henselae and B. Quintana.  Bartonella henselae is most often transmitted through a cat scratch or bite, though ticks and fleas may also act as a vector.  Bartonella quintana is usually transmitted by lice. It can manifest in people with AIDS and rarely appears in those who are immunocompetent

questions.text: A patient came for removal of tattoo. Which of the following devices can be used?
A newborn had reddish swelling over upper eyelid. There was no lid edema or eye involvement and the swelling regressed spontaneously at about one year of age. What is the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Salmon patch (Nevus Simplex)

  • Salmon patches are small, pale pink, ill- defined, vascular macules that occur most commonly on the glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area of 30-40% of normal newborn infants.
  • These lesions, which represent localized vascular ectasia, persist for several months and may become more visible during crying or changes in environmental temperature.
  • Most lesions on the face eventually fade and disappear completely, but those on the posterior neck and occipital areas often persist.
  • The facial lesions should not be confused with a port-wine stain, which is a permanent lesion.
  • The salmon patch is usually symmetric, with lesions on both eyelids and both sides of midline.
  • Port-wine stains are often larger and unilateral, and they usually end along the midline

questions.text: Which of the following is characterized by involvement of sweat glands & hair follicle with non caseating epithelioid granuloma?
questions.solution: Histopathology of Lichen scrofulosorum shows hair follicle infiltrated with mononuclear cells and occasional epithelioid cells, and upper dermal granuloma formed by mononuclear cells and epithelioid cells.

choices.text: Aplastic anemia in sickle cell disease

questions.text: A baby presented with fever and rash, as shown in the image. Which of the following condition is NOT caused by virus that causes this disease?
questions.solution: Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease):- This is caused by the human parvovirus B19 and occurs in outbreaks, often in the spring. A slapped cheek erythema is quickly followed by a reticulate erythema of the shoulders. The affected child feels well, and the rash clears over the course of a few days. Other features, sometimes not accompanied by a rash, include transient anaemia and arthritis.

questions.text: A patient vitiligo universalis presnts to you in the OPD. He wants the removal of few pigmented lesions on the face to get a uniform skin color. Which of the following medications can be prescribed ?
questions.solution:
Depigmentation therapy refers to medical treatments that remove skin pigmentation causing contact leukoderma. Depigmentation therapy is used in someone that has widespread, but incomplete, vitiligo on the face and/or other sites, in an attempt to improve their appearance.

The most commonly used depigmenting agent is monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH). If the patient cannot tolerate MBEH, or if treatment fails, combination therapies or other treatments may be considered.

MBEH or monobenzone is the most commonly used depigmenting agent used in vitiligo. It is the only depigmentation treatment for extensive vitiligo that has been approved by the FDA (Food and Drug Agency, United States of America). MBEH is a derivative of hydroquinone. Unlike hydroquinone, it almost always causes irreversible depigmentation, as it results in death of melanocytes.

Other agents - phenol, NDYAG laser

questions.text: A patient presents with rashes all over body with erosions of the lips and other mucosa since 2 days. What can be the triggering factor?
questions.solution:
• Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is a potentially life-threatening dermatologic disorder characterized by widespread (TEN involves more than 30% of the body surface, whereas SJS involves less than 10%) erythema, necrosis, and bullous detachment of the epidermis and mucous membranes, resulting in exfoliation and possible sepsis and/or death. Mucous membrane involvement can result in gastrointestinal hemorrhage, respiratory failure, ocular abnormalities, and genitourinary complications.
  • TEN is most commonly treated by drug-induced antibiotics (sulfonamides), antiepileptic drugs (Phenobarbital, Phenytoin), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), ampicillin, allopurinol, and the antiretroviral drugs (nevirapine, abacavir).
  • The mainstay of treatment is supportive care until the epithelium regenerates.

questions.text: Diagnosis
questions.solution:
Trichotillomania

  • Trichotillomania is a behavioral disorder characterized by compulsive hair-pulling
  • It presents as a pattern of hair loss, often bizarre, with no clear biological or overt traumatic explanation.
  • Hair is plucked most frequently from one frontoparietal region.
  • This results in a patch of hair loss, often in a bizarre or angular pattern, in which the hairs are twisted and broken at various distances from the clinically normal scalp.

Decreased hair density, hairs broken at different lengths, short hairs with trichoptilosis ('split ends') Irregular coiled hairs and upright re-growing hairs are also reported

Flame hairs are semi-transparent, wavy and cone-shaped hair residues, which develop as a result of severe mechanical hair pulling and shredding. V-sign is created when two or more hairs emerge from one follicular ostium, which are pulled simultaneously and break at the same length above scalp surface. Tulip hairs are short hairs with darker, tulip flower shaped ends. These hairs develop when a hair shaft fractures diagonally. When hair shafts are almost totally damaged by mechanical manipulation, only a sprinkled hair residue is visible. This finding is referred to as hair powder. < /p>

questions.text: A mason presents with these lesions on the hands. A patch test is done. which of these is most likely to be positive?
questions.solution:
• Most common allergen is hexavalent chromium salts
  • Allergic contact dermatitis more than irritant contact dermatitis.
  • Level of exposure needed for allergic contact dermatitis 100-400 ng/cm2.
  • Tartrate, glycine, silicone, dapsone, ferrous sulphate causes conversion from chromium (VI) to chromium (III), which is less allergenic.

questions.text: Haascheiben cells in epidermis are responsible for:
questions.solution:
• In addition to keratinocytes, melanocytes, Langerhans cell and indeterminate cell in the epidermis, Merkel celli /Haascheiben/Touch cells are found at the base of the epidermal rete ridges and they are in contact with nerve fibrils
  • They are mostly present in palms, soles, nail beds, oral and genital epithelium and act as slow touch.

questions.text: This sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Darter's sign: When Dermographism is limited to skin overlying a lesion (macule or papule): Diagnostic of Urticaria pigmentosa (mast cell disease)
  • Pseudo Darier's sign: It is seen in congenital smooth muscle hamartoma

questions.text:
Desmoglein is associated with
1. Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy
2. Hypertrichosis
3. Pemphigus vulgaris
4. Psoriasis
5. Keratoderma with wooly hair
questions.solution:
• Hypotrichosis is associated with desmoglein 4, not hypertrichosis.
  • The psoriasis-susceptibility (PSORS1) locus within the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on chromosome 6p21 (location of the HLA genes) is considered a major genetic determinant of psoriasis . Among other MHC genes that have been associated with psoriasis, HLA-Cw6 is the most important allele for susceptibility to early-onset psoriasis. HLA-Cw6 also demonstrates a strong association with guttate psoriasis. HLA-B17 may be associated with a propensity for psoriasis and more severe psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text:
Dermatologic manifestation of lithium is/are:
1. Rash
2. Psoriasis exacerbation
3. Acneiform eruptions
4. Pustular dermatoses
5. Pemphigus
questions.solution:
The skin is the organ most commonly adversely affected by lithium.

Men are more likely to be affected.
Lithium has a higher rate of causing adverse skin effects compared to other psychotropic drugs used for mood disorders.
Compared to other organ systems, adverse effects of the skin occur even if serum lithium is still in the normal therapeutic range.

- It can cause the first presentation of a skin disease or can exacerbate an existing disease, such as psoriasis or acne.
- Lithium can also trigger other types of psoriasis, such as palmoplantar pustulosis, generalised pustular psoriasis, nail psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis.

- Hair loss affects 12–19% of patients on long-term lithium therapy.
- Other skin diseases that have been reported in association with lithium include:

Generalised morbilliform eruption and exfoliative dermatitis

Cutaneous and mucosal/mouth ulcers

Various forms of eczema/dermatitis

Generalised pruritus and dry skin

Pityriasis versicolor

Darier disease

Dermatitis herpetiformis and other immunobullous eruptions

Hidradenitis suppurative

Drug-induced lupus erythematosus.
